STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 21, 2022
Natasha Doan-Motsinger
Our House
111 S. Wallace Blvd.
Ypsilanti, MI 48197
RE: License #: CB810406448
Our House
111 S. Wallace Blvd.
Ypsilanti, MI 48197
Dear Ms. Doan-Motsinger:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
1/11/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of three employee files did not have a clearance on file. The employee was a
rehire and a new clearance was not completed at the time of rehire.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
Three of three IL case files did not have a service plan completed within 30 days of
accepting the case.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
Three of three IL case files did not have documentation the program statement was
provided to the youth prior to placement.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
Three of three IL case files did not have documentation the policies & procedures
were provided to the youth prior to placement.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
4

days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to
meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous
expenses.
Three of three IL case files did not have budgets completed on a monthly basis.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three IL case records held a contract which was not signed by the youth.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violations listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Page 6
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure, the caseworker must document…
One of one closed case file did not have a closing DHS-69 competed to document
requirements of this policy.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 One case that was accepted in November 2021, held a photo that was almost
out of date. The agency was advised to update photos at the time of case intake.
 It was recommended the agency develop an AWOL checklist outlining the
requirements of licensing rules and policy FOM 722-03A. This tool could be used
to help guide staff, as well as document required notifications.
 The agency was reminded that a budget must be completed with youth monthly
and a review of their contract at least every 90 days. The agency must also
document the youth received a copy of the reviewed contract. Documentation
could be a statement with the youth’s signature on the contract form.
 Family Team Meetings must be completed at least 30 days prior to completing a
USP. The agency is advised to review policy FOM 722-06B regarding the
triggers for an FTM. In addition, the agency was advised to ensure all
5

participants sign the 1105 report after an FTM; if the FTM was held virtually staff
should note the meeting was held virtually and list the attendees.
 The agency was reminded that all contacts must be entered into MiSACWIS
within 5 business days.
 The agency was advised of policy FOM 801-1 (page 7) regarding required
documentation if an IL youth refused medical or dental exams as required by
rules and policy.
 The agency is currently utilizing their handbook to acclimate IL youth to the
program. The Chief Administrator was advised if the program statement and
policies/procedures are part of this book, the agency must document these items
were reviewed with the youth prior to placement.
 The agency was advised a service plan is required by licensing rules within 30
days of accepting a case. This does not need to be a full USP, but it needs to
document the information required by Rule 418(3).
 The agency was advised that IL youth must sign their treatment plan within 30
days of the USP/PATP report date, per FOM 722-08D.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility requested consultation regarding staffing the IL house with staff that are
the opposite gender of the youth in the home. The CA was advised there are no
rules against such staffing. However, clear policies and procedures should be in
place to ensure youth and staff are safe and appropriate. The CA indicated security
cameras are in the home and clear staff boundaries are already in place. DCWL
suggested considering a second staff in the IL house, to provide a second set of
eyes should any problems arise. The CA indicated they will continue to evaluate the
situation before making any decisions.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency was not required to submit any corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was discussed with the Chief Administrator
(CA) during the entrance meeting on 1/11/22. As this is the first six months of
licensure, the CA reported spending a lot of time putting their initial plans into
practice. The CA reported it has been a learning process, but they are getting
stronger and will continue intentional, paced, growth. Thus far, the agency has
provided IL services to four youth. Three youth remain in the program, and one went
AWOL. Overall, the CA reported they have begun developing positive relationships
with the local DHHS office, law enforcement and other community partners. The CA
was advised DCWL is always available for consultation as they continue to learn
more about the child welfare system. As the agency staff continue to learn the
6

nuances of child welfare, abundant technical assistance was provided throughout
the review, which the CA reported to find helpful.
Interviews
Two staff were interviewed and reported the past six months has been a positive
learning experience. The staff did not share any concerns at this time.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
A field analyst review was not completed as this agency services Independent Living
youth only.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes, rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
_ ________________January 20, 2022____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 21, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
